column4: I have two machines, both of which are secured with good passwords, but both are shared environments as well.  How safe would it be to use a shared key without a passphrase to authenticate between these two machines?
does anyone else have access to your machines?
yes, they are shared environments.
some users have sudo, most do not though
if you trust the users who do have sudo to not screw around with your other machine, then it should be fine as long as you turn off read permissions for others
but if you can't trust the super users, then keep your keys passworded and use ssh-agent
I feel like I can trust them, but the thing is I need a way to have this automated.  It's for a nightly backup script
Which will be handled with cron job
a cron job*
look into making ssh keys that can only execute one command then log out
Like, a specific command, or just any one command?
a specific command, you can setup a key to login and only execute a specified command
Awesome, thanks.  I'll look into it.
make a script on the server to do your build and transfer files, then have the ssh key run that script
Alright, thanks Nallep
so, what you're saying is one script to make the backup files, one script to send the files off, and one script to execute the file sending?  third script executes second, which executes the first
And the third script is called in with cron
well depends on what your doing, I'd just put it all in one script and execute it all at once
Alright, I'll see what I can dig up on Google.  Thanks for the help, Nal
Nallep*
look into the command option for your authorized_keys file (read man authorized_keys)
